liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just because we have no economic data locally today doesn't mean it's going to stay that way for the rest of the week. Here's a quick look at what's happening this week, and what you can expect to see us covering in the blog (or, if you want them for your own diary): Tuesday: UK unemployment rate for July Wednesday: Apple to unveil iPhone 15 (AEST) Wednesday: US CPI (inflation) data Wednesday: UK GDP figures (monthly, for July) Thursday: Australian employment data for August Thursday: US jobless claims Thursday: US Core Producer Price Index (monthly) Thursday: Europe Central Bank rates decision Friday: US consumer sentiment (September) Friday: US industrial production (August) Friday: China activity data (retail sales, unemployment, industrial production) Friday: People's Bank of China medium-term lending facility decision
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's happening this week?

children.content: Just because we have no economic data locally today doesn't mean it's going to stay that way for the rest of the week.
, and what you can expect to see us covering in the blog (or, if you want them for your own diary):

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A range of organisations are joining forces at the Australian Renewables Industry Summit in Canberra to call for new policies to fund renewable energy projects. The think tank "Climate Energy Finance" is part of a consortium asking the government to commit to a 10-year, $100-billion package for the renewables industry. Founder and director Tim Buckley says the government's current commitments mean Australia will fall short of its potential on the world stage. You can watch his full chat with News Breakfast's Michael Rowland below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ðŸ“º Investors, unions and businesses team up to call for $100 billion, 10-year renewable energy package

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're struggling with another Monday, and the idea of a four-day working week sounds appealing, then I have some good news for you â€”it's gaining momentum in Australia. Unions have started to embed trials of a four-day work week into industrial agreements, and another five to 10 organisations are currently in discussions with the Australian Services Union as more agreements start being negotiated. So what is the idea exactly? It's all about cutting working hours down to a 32-hour work week in a four-day period, with no loss of pay, and there are many models that companies can use. A government report recently called for agencies to begin trialling the concept, in response to a trial in Australian businesses that found more than 95 per cent of those continued with it. Want to know more? Tap the link below to read the full story by my very productive colleague, business reporter Daniel Ziffer :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Like the idea of a four-day working week? It's a step closer to becoming mainstream

featuredLink.title: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading
